texts.shortText: Large, smooth-shelled brown mussel, sometimes tinged with green or (in juveniles) with a chevron pattern. Eroded areas of the shell white or silvery. May form dense beds in lower intertidal zone and then become elongated, almost square in cross-section, and dented where rub against neighbours. Internally, gonads of females orange and those of males off-white. Resilial ridge (narrow white band alongside the hinge ligament on inner surface of shell) finely pitted.
Reaches 125 mm in deeper water, but intertidal specimens seldom exceed 90 mm shell length.

Global: Widespread across the western Indian Ocean and Atlantic coast of South America, as well as Namibia. Introduced to Gulf coast of USA.

Local/Regional: Namibia and south and east coasts of South Africa, but absent from west coast.

Primarily a warmer-water species that forms dense intertidal beds on rocky shores from False Bay eastwards along the south and especially east coasts of South Africa, where it is commonly collected for human consumption. Absent from the west coast but then, surprisingly, reappears again in Namibia.

Along the south coast occurs in mixed beds with the Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis, but there is some separation between the species as Perna has a stronger byssal attachment to the rocks, so is more tolerant of wave-exposed sites, whereas Mytilus can tolerate longer periods of aerial exposure, so dominates at higher tidal levels. Was once abundant in False Bay, but is now rare there and restricted to a few shallow, warmer sites because of declining sea temperatures occurring in this area over the past few decades.

All mussels feed by drawing water in though a distal and ventral inhalant siphon, which is surrounded by branched lobes to keep out particles too large to be consumed. The water is then filtered thought the enlarged sieve-like gills and ejected though a dorsal smooth-edged exhalent siphon. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth at the anterior (pointed) end, where they are sorted by the labial palps and lighter particles ingested. Inedible particles are rejected by the palps and ejected as ‘pseudo faeces’ which has not passed thought the digestive tract.

Mussels are unusual in that the gonad permeates throughout the body and when ripe can make up more than 50% of the total body weight. Spawning is usually synchronised via hormones released with the sperm and eggs and after spawning ‘spent’ individuals are thin and flaccid. Spawning is triggered by temperature changes and in temperate areas occurs predictably in spring and sometimes also autumn. However, in South Africa sea temperatures show much more seasonal stability and spawning tends to be more irregular and is probably triggered by short-term upwelling events. The numbers of eggs produced is enormous, running to the millions per mussel and hence billions per square meter of mussel bed! Larval development takes about 30 days and juvenile mussels (spat) sometimes settle in densities of hundreds of thousands per square meter.

In this species males are more common (64%) and females (36%). The breeding season has been documented in several different areas and differs between sites (and/or years). There is usually either one extended breeding season, or two discreet events.

The brown colour is fairly distinctive and a reliable identification feature, but could be confused with the introduced Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis, as they often occur in mixed beds. The shells of Perna are more elongate and shorter in the vertical dimension. There are also differences in the adductor muscle scars on the inside of the shells (Perna has one anterior scar and a divided posterior scar and Mytilus two anterior scars and an undivided posterior one - see Van Erkom Schurink paper listed below for diagrams showing differences.
